componenttextpreview: Thank you for taking the question. Hi, John, just wanted to ask your opinion on -- given that after this quarter, sounds like there’s still going to be, I don’t know, you say seven to 10 million drives of excess inventory out there for the industry. M
componenttext: Thank you for taking the question. Hi, John, just wanted to ask your opinion on -- given that after this quarter, sounds like there’s still going to be, I don’t know, you say seven to 10 million drives of excess inventory out there for the industry. Might it, might it be, I guess, more prudent to ship, I guess, sort of a TAM down the December quarter versus September just to get that out of the way more quickly or is there something structural just about the way, you know, that you take down -- the industry collectively takes down the bill price of the quarter that precludes that from being done?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: You know, our take on the TAM and calling the TAM flat quarter to quarter here, we believe the underlying demand is up quarter to quarter. We think there’s -- it is seasonal and will likely be up in the 5% range on a quarter-over-quarter basis. And we
componenttext: You know, our take on the TAM and calling the TAM flat quarter to quarter here, we believe the underlying demand is up quarter to quarter. We think there’s -- it is seasonal and will likely be up in the 5% range on a quarter-over-quarter basis. And we’re, we’re calling the drive industry TAM flat so that the inventory that has been built up can be absorbed the market demand.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. Thanks. And I guess just a quick follow-up on that. Any sense -- is it too early to get a sense -- if taking out, you know, through the inventory that will be taken out during the December quarter by shipping the flat TAM, will that make a meaning
componenttext: Got it. Thanks. And I guess just a quick follow-up on that. Any sense -- is it too early to get a sense -- if taking out, you know, through the inventory that will be taken out during the December quarter by shipping the flat TAM, will that make a meaningful difference in the promotion of, you know, more normal seasonal pricing in the March quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think March quarter, you know, the thesis is yet to be proven. But we do believe that there is some shift to the overall traditional seasonality of the industry and unfortunately the timing of the big recession makes it -- and the recovery out of that -
componenttext:
I think March quarter, you know, the thesis is yet to be proven. But we do believe that there is some shift to the overall traditional seasonality of the industry and unfortunately the timing of the big recession makes it -- and the recovery out of that -- makes it very difficult to clearly discern shifts in the multi-year seasonal patterns. But we do believe that there is a (inaudible) of the rise of China as an important market, creating demand in the first calendar quarter of the year.
We believe there is a shift from air freight to sea freight from Asia to the U.S. and Europe causing a shift, a pull forward of back to school builds into the second calendar quarter of the year. And that we’re, over time, the seasonality of the business will flatten out. But it’s, it’s difficult to get a precise handle on that because of the massive disruption that the recession put on top of those patterns.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. Thanks a lot. Appreciate it.
componenttext: Got it. Okay. Thanks a lot. Appreciate it.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark Moskowitz with J.P. Morgan, your line is open.
componenttext: Mark Moskowitz with J.P. Morgan, your line is open.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. Thank you. Good afternoon. Two questions if I could. I want to come back to just what has been going on here over the past six months or so. John and Tim, if you could kind of weigh in here. Is there something that’s structurally wrong right now w
componenttext:
Yeah. Thank you. Good afternoon. Two questions if I could. I want to come back to just what has been going on here over the past six months or so. John and Tim, if you could kind of weigh in here. Is there something that’s structurally wrong right now with the overall disk drive industry in terms of how the industry interfaces with both the OEMs and the distributors?
And I think back to 2004 how there was a lot of challenges and the industry participants worked to have greater transparency and greater dialogue to manage the inventories and supply demand and balances. Because I just get confused when you can have this huge 13th week and then suddenly the spigot gets turned off again by the OEMs. I mean, are they having these quick solid demand cycles? Who’s kind of at fault here in terms of what is going on?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, what you’re seeing is competitive behavior in a slightly -- just slightly unbalanced supply demand situation. It is very typical. We saw -- we have never before seen in the industry four sequential quarters where the demand presented to the indu
componenttext:
I mean, what you’re seeing is competitive behavior in a slightly -- just slightly unbalanced supply demand situation. It is very typical. We saw -- we have never before seen in the industry four sequential quarters where the demand presented to the industry outstripped the industry’s demand for supply -- ability to supply. And it’s pretty natural coming out of that that the pendulum is going to swing back a little the other way. It is very difficult to land without a little over shoot.
And so I think what you have seen in the last six months has been, you know, the wealth created in the four quarter runoff allowed people to -- encourage everybody to get more invested in the industry. And initially, as the demand softened, people have tried to maintain their momentum. And it takes a little while for folks to realize that the -- if everybody overbuilds then there’s going to be pressure and then there is going to be -- you know, our customers are smart people. They are going to take advantage of that. And we need to get things back in balance and move on with life. And that is the cycle that has been played through.
I think if you analyze the numbers however, you will see that -- you know things are not a disaster right now. Where we finished last quarter above the bottom of our model, you can go back many years into the last 10 years and find periods where we dropped out of the model for periods of time. And I would remind you that the model was a significantly lower bottom to it that it has today.
So the industry and WD have expanded gross margin model consistently over the last 10 years. And we are still -- you know, yeah, we do not like being under the bottom of the model. And we are going to work to move ourselves back into it as soon as we can but we are also going to work to ensure that we have the right product set and the right availability and the right approach with our customers to have them prefer WD product over others and continue to grow our business profitably.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess as a follow-up then, so should, should the message be then to investors that we could see a Bell curve where you had four kind of medioric quarters and now you’re going to have four quarters of some pretty challenging times? And I say that becau
componenttext: I guess as a follow-up then, so should, should the message be then to investors that we could see a Bell curve where you had four kind of medioric quarters and now you’re going to have four quarters of some pretty challenging times? And I say that because if I think about the industry, to the industry’s credit, you have a lot more efficient and effective participants now than we did say five years or six years ago. And as Rich alluded to earlier, it is going to difficult to kind of reset the price curve, I think, for the time being. So are we…

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I would say to investors is to look at the long-term demand for storage. The fact that the most appropriate solution for mass volume storage is hard drives. And to look at the long-term progress the industry has made in the last 10 years and I believ
componenttext: What I would say to investors is to look at the long-term demand for storage. The fact that the most appropriate solution for mass volume storage is hard drives. And to look at the long-term progress the industry has made in the last 10 years and I believe we will continue on that fundamental trend line over the next 10 years.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

componenttext: So, in closing, I’d like to thank all of you for joining us today. We appreciate your questions and your interest in the company and in the industry. We look forward to seeing you again in another quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's First Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2011. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's First Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2011. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I want to mention, as we begin, that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and our response to your questions concerning the role and growth of digital content; growth opportunities for storage companies and our responses
componenttext:
Thank you. I want to mention, as we begin, that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and our response to your questions concerning the role and growth of digital content; growth opportunities for storage companies and our responses thereto; industry inventory; pricing and demand; our business model; our position in the industry; total available market for hard drives in the December quarter; our expected capital expenditures, depreciation and amortization and tax rate for fiscal 2011; our share repurchase plans; and our financial results, expectations for the December quarter, including revenue, expenses, tax rates, share count and earnings per share. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our 10-K filed with the SEC on August 13, 2010. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events, and you should not assume later in the quarter that the comments we make today are still valid.
I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investor section of Western Digital's website immediately following the conclusion of this call. I would now like turn to the call over to President and Chief Executive Officer of Western Digital, John Coyne.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. With me are Tim Leyden, recently named Chief Operating Officer; and Wolfgang Nickl, our newly appointed Chief Financial Officer. Although my titles of President and CEO are unchanged, m
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. With me are Tim Leyden, recently named Chief Operating Officer; and Wolfgang Nickl, our newly appointed Chief Financial Officer. 
Although my titles of President and CEO are unchanged, my emphasis has shifted to how we can best leverage our resources to accelerate our growth in the years ahead. As the new leader of all WD operations and keeper of our low cost model, Tim will discuss current industry dynamics and the company's performance in the September quarter while Wolfgang will report on our financial results and provide our outlook for the December quarter. With the advantage of a deeply experienced, dedicated and passionate team, we're excited as we lead WD into its fifth decade. 
As we look out over the next 10 years, the role of digital content in our daily lives at home and in the workplace will become increasingly ubiquitous, with the explosion of data and video rich applications creating huge amounts of digital content that need to be stored and managed. This will be driven by both the traditional computing markets and by new or evolutionary platforms such as handheld devices, televisions and other home entertainment devices for the analog to digital conversion is in its infancy. 
In addition to the continuing growth of traditional PC platforms, the growth of cloud computing, tablet computing and the proliferation of smartphones creates myriad opportunities for storage companies in traditional hard drive and emerging solid state drive markets. We will shape the future of WD by sorting through all these opportunities and acting decisively in our core business and in our business development efforts to continue delivering value to customers and shareholders. 
You have seen some early indications of one new strategic direction for WD into the movement of data and content around the home with our WD TV Live Media Players, our WD My Book Live network storage solutions and most recently, our WD Livewire powerline network offering. Going forward, we are looking for ways in which to pursue strategic growth initiatives such as this, both organically and through acquisition.
Turning to the current hard drive industry environment. We are again reminded that this is a competitive industry of seasons and cycles. The management of supply and demand remains an imperfect science. The moderation in industry demand growth in the last two quarters came on the heels of an unprecedented four quarters of strong sequential growth coming out of the great recession. As an industry, we clearly overshot the recent market demand, and we have spent the last six months correcting for that. We believe this will prove to be an interlude to the resumption of the industry's traditional cadence of growth over the last 10 years. 
Having said this, it's important to note that growth has not disappeared in the hard drive industry post recession. Expected year-on-year volume growth in calendar year 2010 of 15% brings the five-year industry compound growth rate, which includes the recession of late 2008 to about 11%, while the average growth rate over the last 10 years has been 12.5%. 
In the last two quarters, some competitors have made aggressive bids to recover market share. This is a scenario we have seen play out from time to time over the years in the drive industry. Our observation is that these are temporary skirmishes, which do not derail our fundamental long-term profitable growth story as we address these challenges with the tested business model we have developed and honed over time.
For the last 10 years, WD has been navigating these industry swings and consistently winning share with our focus on customer value by having the lowest cost model in the industry. We have grown revenues by 18% annually over the last 10 years and by 22% annually for the last five years by providing exceptional value to our customers through the high quality, reliability and desirability of our products along with predictable availability and competitive prices. At the same time, we have expanded our full year gross margins from 11% in 2001 to 24% in 2010. This was accomplished primarily through successful vertical integration, expanding our product breadth, delighting our customers and execution of our low-cost model. We will continue with this approach as we go forward. Tim Leyden, will now comment on how the September quarter played out for WD and the industry.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As John indicated, we have navigated through multiple market-driven supply/demand imbalances in the hard drive industry. And WD remains prepared to address them with what we believe is the industry's lowest cost model. Continuing our unwavering
componenttext:
Thank you. As John indicated, we have navigated through multiple market-driven supply/demand imbalances in the hard drive industry. And WD remains prepared to address them with what we believe is the industry's lowest cost model. Continuing our unwavering focus on low-cost leadership is my top priority in my new position. This couples with the focus on staying on the industry area density curve, a continued appreciation of customer needs and a broad and diverse set of competitive product offerings in all segments will keep us in an advantage position. This proven approach to the hard drive business has served us, our customers and our shareholders well for the last 10 years. 
As John mentioned earlier, we saw an unprecedented four consecutive quarters of increasing hard drive shipments from April 2009 to March 2010. And it is now apparent that we have been experiencing a correction of PC makers inventories beginning in the June quarter of this year. 
Despite weak demand for the first two months of the September quarter and the quite-than-normal back-to-school season, industry shipments nevertheless climbed towards the high end of our 165 million unit forecast for the September quarter. But to accomplish this, shipment volumes in week 13 were over twice the average of the previous 12 weeks. 
In light of the sluggish demand in July and August, we reduced our bill plans for September, delayed our capital spending and selectively step back from participating in some very aggressive pricing at the end of the quarter. The lower-than-expected demand earlier in the quarter made to a build up of manufacturers inventory during the first eight weeks of the quarter. And contrary to prior fiscal first quarter historical trend, this contributed to aggressive pricing during the reminder of the quarter. 
We maintained share in the 3.5-inch market and yielded 1.5 points of share in 2.5-inch as a result of our temporary process. We exited the quarter with well-controlled inventories in each of our segments. 
We expect that the incremental parts of the week 13 shipments will be consumed during the current quarter because customers will not wish to carry this inventory into a seasonally weaker March quarter. And we believe this sets the stage for a TAM in the December quarter that will be essentially flat with the September quarter.
We believe that HDD hardware and software are pivotal to the data and content management infrastructure ecosystem. The value delivers is not proportionately rewarded in the broader market space, particularly even the level of unique skills and investments in technology and capital are taken into consideration. 
Consequently, we under the midst of reviewing the comparative returns on investments that we are currently achieving across our customer and product ranges, with the view to reaching the levels of ROI we need in order to continue investing and to provide a product availability with the market demand. As the industry's lowest cost provider, we believe that it is in the best interest of our customers and shareholders that we offer products at a price that covers the cost of doing business and provides the margin and the funding required to continue investing in order to remain a valued HDD supplier on a long-term sustainable basis.
Looking at our served markets in the September quarter. In the compute space, we saw a continuation of softness in consumer demand in all channels, with somewhat of an offset coming from healthier desktop and commercial notebook demand. We expect desktop demand to be marginally down and notebook demand to be marginally up in the December quarter. 
In the Enterprise segment, we saw a continued demand strength particularly in Enterprise SATA with the traditional Enterprise segment being essentially flat sequentially. We expect overall Enterprise demand to show us some modest growth in the December quarter. 
In the non-compute space, we saw the CE market volume decline marginally quarter-on-quarter as the market track historical seasonal demand pattern. At the same time, the branded products market showed seasonal demand strength to both 3.5-inch and 2.5-inch categories showing growth. We expect the non-compute space to be essentially flat in the December quarter, and healthy volume increases in branded and CE are offset by the seasonal declines in gaming volume. 
Geographically, Asia has showed continued strength. Europe showed the best comparative improvements from the previous quarter helped by the currency appreciation, while the U.S. market was up modestly from the prior quarter. 
We shipped 50.7 million units in the September quarter, up 15% from the year-ago period while the overall market grew by 8%. Revenues totaled $2.4 billion, gross margin was 18.2%, and we remain solidly profitable with net income of $197 million.  Importantly, we continue to generate strong cash flow from operations of $390 million.
We continue to invest in the business and are doing so by improving and expanding our operation and by enhancing our product lineup, both in our industry-leading hard drive offerings and in the recent but promising market for management of content in the home. 
In our traditional businesses, we delivered new models of our popular My Book and My Passport external hard drives with USB 3.0 connectivity and up to three terabytes of storage. Significantly improving content transfer speed and providing our customers with future proofing as newer PCs and other devices began shipping in volume with USB 3.0. And in the component space, we began shipping the highest area of infancy, 3.5-inch hard drive in the industry, the WD Caviar bringing three terabytes, which fits 750 gigabytes on each of its four platters. 
Reflecting our increasing focus on enabling our comprehensive and easy-to-use experience for management of content in the home, we've added several new products and features including the WD Livewire powerline AV network kit, a home plug AV compatible solution that enables consumers to use their existing electrical wiring to extend secure high-speed Internet connection throughout the home. 
The My Book Live home network drive, which gives consumers the fastest storage of and access to their content and provides the same set up centralizing digital media in the home. The one terabyte WD Elements play multimedia drive, with high-definition capability onboard, and we also recently introduced the newest version of WD Photos or photo viewer application now optimize for the iPad, the iPhone 4 and iPod Touch. WD Photos enable users to view photos stored on their WD home network drive from any location. I will now turn the call over to Wolfgang Nickl for a review of our Q1 financial performance and our outlook for the second quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tim. I would like to refer you to a new and expanded summary of financial information that has been posted to the Investor Relations section of our website. Much of the data that we have resided during past conference calls is included in that
componenttext:
Thank you, Tim. I would like to refer you to a new and expanded summary of financial information that has been posted to the Investor Relations section of our website. Much of the data that we have resided during past conference calls is included in that fact sheet. During my prepared remarks, I will focus on highlights and significant changes in some of our key metrics. At the end of this call, the summary of financial information will be updated to include our Q2 guidance, which I will discuss in a few moments.
The September quarter was characterized by unusually aggressive pricing that lasted throughout the quarter with like-for-like prices decline in excess of 8%. Pricing pressure was most prevalent in the 2.5-inch segment. We made a conscious decision to limit our participation in the segment in an effort to optimize profitability. Our flexible operating model allowed us to adjust our operating expenses to offset the impact of pricing on operating margin and closed the quarter near the midpoint of our EPS guidance range. 
We actively managed capital receipts and working capital and generated significant free cash flow. Revenue for the first fiscal quarter was $2.4 billion, up 9% from the prior year and 1% sequentially. This include its $51 million of sales of media from our newly acquired Singapore media facility to fulfill contractual obligation carrying over from Hoya's existing sales commitment. We do not expect any external media sales in Q2. 
Authorized shipments totaled 50.7 million units, up 15% from the prior year period and 2% sequentially. Revenue from sales of WD TV Media Player, WD Livewire network kit and stock solid state drive totals approximately $33 million, roughly flat with the prior year and up 22% from the June quarter. 
Average hard drive selling price was approximately $46 per unit, down $3 from the year-ago quarter and down $1 from the June quarter. Revenue from sales of our branded products including WD TV and WD Livewire product was $425 million, up 11% from $382 million in the year-ago quarter and 6% sequentially from $400 million in the June quarter. 
There was no customer that comprised 10% or more of our total revenue. Our first margin for the quarter was 18.2%, down from 23.3% in the year-ago quarter and down from 22.5% in the June quarter. The lower-than-expected gross margin percentage was primarily due to the price declines I referred to earlier. Products and segment mix, as well as product cost declines, were largely in line with our expectations.
Total R&D and SG&A spending was $226 million or 9.4% of revenue. This compares with $195 million or 8.8% of revenue in the year-ago quarter and $242 million or 10.2% of revenue in the June quarter. As a reminder, total operating expenses for the June quarter include a $27 million of litigation settlement. 
Operating income was $211 million or 8.8% of revenue. This compares with $319 million or 14.4% of revenue in the year-ago quarter and $293 million or 12.3% of revenue in the June quarter. Net interest and other nonoperating expenses were less than $1 million. 
Tax expense for the September quarter was $14 million or 6.6% of pretax income. Our net income totaled $197 million or $0.84 per share. This compares with $288 million or $1.25 per share and $265 million or $1.13 per share in the year-ago and June quarter, respectively.
Turning to the balance sheet. We generated $390 million in cash flow from operations during the September quarter. Our cash conversion cycle for the first quarter was a negative three days. This consisted of 50 days of receivables outstanding, 26 days of inventory or 14 turns and 79 days of payables. 
Capital addition for the September quarter totaled $200 million, lower than our July projections of $275 million as we scaled back in line with lower shipments. Depreciation and amortization expense for the first quarter totaled $115 million. We continue to expect our capital expenditure for fiscal 2011 to be between 7% and 8% of revenue with an additional $200 million related to our 6-inch to 8-inch wafer conversion and some expenditures to optimize the output from our recently acquired media facility in Singapore. Depreciation and amortization is expected to be at about $630 million for the fiscal year. 
We made $25 million of debt repayment installments during the first quarter, and thereby reduced our debt balance to $375 million. We exited fiscal Q1 with cash and cash equivalent of $2.9 billion, an increase of $124 million from the June quarter. Here in the quarter, we repurchased 1.8 million shares at a total cost of $50 million. The balance remaining on our stock repurchase authorization is $416 million. From a balance sheet strategy perspective, our first priority is to create shareholder value through strategic investments both in markets currently served and adjacent markets. Any larger scale share buybacks would be considered only after we have exhausted our strategic options. 
Now turning to our expectations for fiscal Q2. Historically, industry shipment increased by 5% to 7% from the September to the December quarter. As Tim mentioned, we have seen approximately twice the shipment volume in the last week of last quarter than an average of the preceding 12 weeks of the quarter. We believe that customers will not want to carry extra inventory into the March quarter and therefore, expect some inventory correction. We consequently assume that the December quarter industry TAM will be roughly flat with the September quarter at around 165 million units. 
Some of the aggressive pricing we have seen last quarter is carried over into this quarter, and our guidance includes like-for-like pricing line of approximately 5%. We are actively reviewing our planned shipment portfolio to identify business that is not meeting our business model requirements. We have contractual obligations do not exist. We may refuse our shipments to low contribution products and seek to shift sales to more profitable segment. 
As previously indicated, we are currently calibrating our new Singapore media facility through our own recipes, and as a result, we are experiencing a dilution of first margin of 50 basis points during this quarter. Accordingly, our guidance for fiscal Q2 is as follows. We expect revenue to be in the range from $2.3 billion to $2.4 billion. R&D and SG&A spending is expected to total approximately $230 million. Our net interest expense is projected to be about $1 million. Expect our tax rate to be within our business model of 6% to 9%. We anticipate our share count to be approximately $235 million. We estimate earnings per share of between $0.50 and $0.60 for the December quarter. Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just lastly, traditionally, the industry has been able to offset price declines by moving to new product lines. There has been largely an absence of new products here in the second half of calendar '10. They're supposed to be some new products coming out
componenttext: Just lastly, traditionally, the industry has been able to offset price declines by moving to new product lines. There has been largely an absence of new products here in the second half of calendar '10. They're supposed to be some new products coming out in the first half of '11. Do you think that that's the opportunity to go and maybe reset this cost price situation? Any thoughts so what we might be able to see a stabilization of the pricing environment?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we've seen previously from history is that the stabilization of the pricing environment comes when demand exceeds supply, and that has generally been going to the seasonal cadence. It's generally beyond the September and December quarters. So with th
componenttext: What we've seen previously from history is that the stabilization of the pricing environment comes when demand exceeds supply, and that has generally been going to the seasonal cadence. It's generally beyond the September and December quarters. So with the working off of the inventory that has occurred during the course of the September quarter and with the HDD market being up about by 5% versus what would normally be a much stronger position somewhere in the 10% to 12%, I would imagine. And going into a December quarter that's essentially flat, we think that the opportunity will come more from supply chain demand again. So we think that the industry will have to manage inventory supply/demand equilibrium and stabilize that situation, and that will have more of an impact on us than any of the new products as such.

And we're not making any predictions when that would happen, but we'll know that the margin for June quarter usually is seasonally soft.

So consequently, we're running at about 165 and if you take the midpoint of the 170 to 180 million units, you're probably looking at being somewhere between 90% and 95%. You just take the straight math, 165 to 175 is about 94%, so it's probably somewhere in the 90% to 95% range.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't actually mention that we elected not to participate. We mentioned that we selectively step back. In addition to that, even though it's a higher number than we what we would normally see, there's always some extra amount that gets shipped in at t
componenttext: We didn't actually mention that we elected not to participate. We mentioned that we selectively step back. In addition to that, even though it's a higher number than we what we would normally see, there's always some extra amount that gets shipped in at the end of each quarter. So the excess over and above what would normally happen is probably somewhere in the region of about 5 million units or so. And so that has to get worked up, obviously, going into a quarter, which is front-end loaded as opposed to the previous two quarters, which have been heavily back-end loaded. So there's an opportunity for that inventory to get burned off early. We'll just have to wait and see what happens.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: My follow-up then, Tim, is just curious to your discussions with the OEMs as it relates to the demand on the notebook side versus the potential conflict or demand conflict with tablets. How are the OEMs characterizing? And how does that make you think abo
componenttext: My follow-up then, Tim, is just curious to your discussions with the OEMs as it relates to the demand on the notebook side versus the potential conflict or demand conflict with tablets. How are the OEMs characterizing? And how does that make you think about the seasonality in notebook drives in the March quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is John. I'll take this tablet question. From everything we can gather with multiple different stores reporting on tablets, I mean we see the first two quarters of the iPad is about 8 million units, to put it in context, that compares with the first
componenttext: This is John. I'll take this tablet question. From everything we can gather with multiple different stores reporting on tablets, I mean we see the first two quarters of the iPad is about 8 million units, to put it in context, that compares with the first two quarters of the EPC netbook emergence, which was 5 million units first two quarters. So everything we hear indicates that roughly half of the iPad sales are to existing Apple households, and that somewhere in the region of 13% to 15% of the folks buying iPads admit to substituting the iPad for a previously planned PC purchase. And some 23% of purchasers indicate they're buying an iPad as an alternative to a Kindle or other eReader. So what we see, I think, is a complementary additional device sale to the overall ecosystem of content consumption. We think that when you look at the numbers, certainly, there has been some falloff in netbook over the last couple of quarters. They're also -- you have to take the price point of the iPad into account, so likely that over the next several quarters as other tablets emerge, they will address lower price points than the iPad currently occupies. But on overall assessment, we're seeing maybe somewhere in the 10% to 20% impact range on the growth of low-end notebooks, netbook products.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ben Reitzes with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Ben Reitzes with Barclays Capital.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about going beyond the December quarter, if you could, just about some dynamics that are setting up. There's Intel Sandy Bridge which may affect some of the builds from the OEM customers and then there's the emergence of China, which is ki
componenttext: I wanted to ask about going beyond the December quarter, if you could, just about some dynamics that are setting up. There's Intel Sandy Bridge which may affect some of the builds from the OEM customers and then there's the emergence of China, which is kind of changing the seasonality of the whole world. So is there a chance that TAM is flattish like it was again like what it was last year in the March quarter? And does the March quarter potentially represents some light at the end of the tunnel here after this big quarter of adjustment in December?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there is a chance. I mean, March quarter traditionally, if we go back to the pre-recession cadence, it was just slightly down and somewhere in the maybe 3% region. And from a going-forward seasonal viewpoint, it does look as if the strength o
componenttext: Yes, I think there is a chance. I mean, March quarter traditionally, if we go back to the pre-recession cadence, it was just slightly down and somewhere in the maybe 3% region. And from a going-forward seasonal viewpoint, it does look as if the strength of China is changing that dynamic. So there is opportunity there from the situation to improve. So we'll wait and see. But I mean, it's all dependent on the working through the inventory that the PC OEMs have built up and how they manage that than how the difference there has been the history of industry and manage the shipment going into the market. So there's a lot of dynamics on it, but there is an opportunity considering the changing variables that are going such as the Intel Sandy Bridge, the Chinese New Year and the strength of fourth Christmas sales as well. So there's opportunity, and we'll have to wait for it.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I wanted to just address the NAND issue again perhaps with Apple having an event tomorrow where they might introduce more NAND into the MacBook Air and whatnot. Is there anything changed more in the mainstream PC market? Or is there any worries a
componenttext: And then I wanted to just address the NAND issue again perhaps with Apple having an event tomorrow where they might introduce more NAND into the MacBook Air and whatnot. Is there anything changed more in the mainstream PC market? Or is there any worries about what Apple may do actually more of the mainstream PC market with NAND? Or is that a status quo still right now where it's too expensive and it's not going to happen and it's just going to be in the iPad market or at the tablet market?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we believe that the solid state solutions are not competitive in the mainstream PC market whether laptop or desktop. The economics just don't work out. Where the storage element is constrained by form factor, then on a high price point devices, solid
componenttext: Yes, we believe that the solid state solutions are not competitive in the mainstream PC market whether laptop or desktop. The economics just don't work out. Where the storage element is constrained by form factor, then on a high price point devices, solid state is an appropriate solution and where in the very small form factor devices like PDAs, MP3 players and so on. It's clear that small amounts of solid state memory are the solution to fit in the form factor and fit in the budget.

Can you talk a little bit to that?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I will not give you specifics on that for competitive reasons, but if you look at the trust of our product offerings in our branded business, you'll note that we've migrated the backup software, on all of our drive products, the My Book and the My Passpor
componenttext: I will not give you specifics on that for competitive reasons, but if you look at the trust of our product offerings in our branded business, you'll note that we've migrated the backup software, on all of our drive products, the My Book and the My Passport line, which used to be a purchase software solution we have migrated to an internally developed solutions so that we can better own the total customer experience there and the interaction of the customer with the device. If you look at our complete range of WD media players, the TV Live line and the Elements play line, there, again, you'll see significant software content in those products. And then you look at the our recent launch of the WD Photo app for the iPad, iPhone 4, and iPod Touch, again an in-house developed software product. So also, some years ago, you will recall we bought a company called [indiscernible]  Was a software play that we have developed into the major engine that creates the connectivity and accessibility for all of our products as they interplay for remote access. So yes, we're putting significant emphasis on software these days.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: One just on CapEx. It did come in a little lower in dollar terms and you mentioned you're still looking at the same target as a percentage of revenue and including the 8-inch wafer conversion. But can you tell us what you've seen maybe from sort of across the industry in terms of other players if you've seen people already cutting CapEx measurably or just starting to a little bit including, for example, Asian media suppliers if you think that's going to help anytime soon or are we too early for CapEx cut to the help? And then separate from that, if I could just push maybe a little more, you did touch on almost the $11 in cash per share that you have. I'm just wondering if you push a little more in terms of what your priorities are in terms of buybacks versus potential dividend and versus acquisitions.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, from a CapEx viewpoint, we don't really have much than our competitors. We would imagine that by past history that people are -- since the volumes are coming in lower than what pipeline have anticipated in September and December quarters of our sect
componenttext: Okay, from a CapEx viewpoint, we don't really have much than our competitors. We would imagine that by past history that people are -- since the volumes are coming in lower than what pipeline have anticipated in September and December quarters of our section for TAM being flattish from September is correct. We would imagine that everybody is moving to postpone and cancel their profitability and capital additions and managing it as prudently as they possibly can. In our case, we have demonstrated that capability over a long period of time. We had capacity just in time, and we managed success on an ongoing basis in order to cover the demand at that point in time.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of balance sheet and stock rebooked as a strategy, as John mentioned in his remarks, our prime focus right now is to evaluate strategic opportunities, what was in 8 gbs as well as in the adjacent markets, and we'll use our cash and our borrowing
componenttext: In terms of balance sheet and stock rebooked as a strategy, as John mentioned in his remarks, our prime focus right now is to evaluate strategic opportunities, what was in 8 gbs as well as in the adjacent markets, and we'll use our cash and our borrowing capacity to accomplish that. And once we have reviewed all these opportunities and will show that we can't find anything appropriate, we will evaluate the best way of returning money to the shareholder, and that could be in the form of share buybacks, and we'll decide whether we do that in a unleveled or leveled fashion at the appropriate point in time.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back and talk about pricing again, because these margins were I think below most of what people thought, you indicated inventory. How much -- you're roughly split 50/50 between the OEM and the channel and retail. How much of the pricing pre
componenttext: I wanted to go back and talk about pricing again, because these margins were I think below most of what people thought, you indicated inventory. How much -- you're roughly split 50/50 between the OEM and the channel and retail. How much of the pricing pressure or the decrease in margin is due to pricing from the OEM options? And how much of it is in your anticipated pricing pressures in the channel?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there has been more pricing pressure coming from OEM. And because during the four quarters of unprecedented demand outstripping supply, the OEMs got nervous about supply, it's up from inventory positions within their own internal inventory. And th
componenttext: I think there has been more pricing pressure coming from OEM. And because during the four quarters of unprecedented demand outstripping supply, the OEMs got nervous about supply, it's up from inventory positions within their own internal inventory. And then we came on a little consumer softness, as they let the inventory correct and then sat back and got some improved pricing conditions as a result of that. And so that dynamic is the more important one in the overall pricing movement. There has been some pressure in the channel as well as in the last couple of quarters you've had given competitors trying to gain back market share that they had lost in earlier quarters and has put some pressure on the channels. But I think the OEM pricing pressure has been more significant.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

Or your still supplying at roughly the same mix internally and externally especially for heads and as well as media by the way?

componenttext: We have very good relationships with the external merchant vendors, and we've got our own internal component operating rather well. That's not a perfect science as you can imagine so it's -- we're continuing to work with them as we always do.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the company we acquired a couple of years ago, we have worked on that embedded market for netcom and industrial controls and so on. And we have grown that business since acquisition, we're committed to that space. We have produced products for the cl
componenttext: Yes, the company we acquired a couple of years ago, we have worked on that embedded market for netcom and industrial controls and so on. And we have grown that business since acquisition, we're committed to that space. We have produced products for the clients space. That's very low volume. And we are working diligently on product for the enterprise space, which we believe is the most attractive application for solid state drives, attractive to the customer because of the value it brings, attractive to us because of the value that we bring to the knowledge in the area of applications and management of media. And so that's our primary focus for now is on the development trail to broaden our enterprise portfolio offering.

componenttext: We think that the enterprise, solid state enterprise market today is somewhere in the $800 million to $1 billion range. And as we assess the various forecast that are out there from multiple sources and our own take on that, we're looking at that market as being a $3 billion to $5 billion market in three to five years.

componenttext: John, just wanted to ask your take on given that after this quarter, it sounds like, there's still going to be, I don't know, you say, $7 million to $10 million drives of excess inventory out there for the industry. Might it be, I guess, more prudent ship, I guess, sort of TAM down in the December quarter versus September just to get that out of the way more quickly? Or is there something structural just about the way that you take down the industry if we take down built planes on the quarter that precluded that from being done?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our take on the time and calling the time flat quarter-to-quarter is we believe the underlying demand is off quarter-to-quarter. We think it's seasonal and will likely be up in the 5% range on a quarter-over-quarter basis, and we're calling to drive indus
componenttext: Our take on the time and calling the time flat quarter-to-quarter is we believe the underlying demand is off quarter-to-quarter. We think it's seasonal and will likely be up in the 5% range on a quarter-over-quarter basis, and we're calling to drive industry TAM flat so that the inventory that has been built up can be absorbed into the market demand.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any sense, or is it too early to get a sense, if taking out through the inventory that will be taken out during the December quarter by shipping the flat TAM? Will that make a meaningful difference in the promotion of more normal seasonal pricing in the M
componenttext: Any sense, or is it too early to get a sense, if taking out through the inventory that will be taken out during the December quarter by shipping the flat TAM? Will that make a meaningful difference in the promotion of more normal seasonal pricing in the March quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think March quarter and the thesis has yet to be proven. But we do believe that there is some shift to the overall traditional seasonality of the industry and unfortunately, the timing of the big recession and the recovery out of that makes it a very di
componenttext: I think March quarter and the thesis has yet to be proven. But we do believe that there is some shift to the overall traditional seasonality of the industry and unfortunately, the timing of the big recession and the recovery out of that makes it a very difficult to clearly discern shifts in the multiyear seasonal patterns, but we do believe that there's a specialty of the rise of China as an important market, creating demand in the first calendar quarter of the year. We believe there's a shift from air freight to sea freight from Asia to the U.S. and Europe causing a shift, a full forward of back-to-school bills into the second calendar quarter of the year and that over time, the seasonality of the business will flatten out. It's difficult to get a precise handle on that because of the massive disruption that the recession pulled on top of those patterns.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to come back to what is going on here over the past six months or so, John and Tim, if you could kind of weigh in here, is there something structurally wrong right now with the overall disk drive industry in terms of how industry interfaces with
componenttext: I wanted to come back to what is going on here over the past six months or so, John and Tim, if you could kind of weigh in here, is there something structurally wrong right now with the overall disk drive industry in terms of how industry interfaces with both the OEMs and distributors? And I think back to 2004, how the results and what are the challenges in any industry participants worth to have greater transparency and greater dialogue to manage the inventories in the supply/demand and balances, because I just got confused when you can have the huge 13th week and then certainly, the space just gets turned off again by the OEMs. I mean, do have these quick static demand cycles? Who's kind of at fault here in terms of what's going on?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, what you're seeing is competitive behavior in a slightly, just slightly unbalanced supply demand situation. And it's very typical. We saw -- we have never before seen in the industry four sequential quarters where the demand presented to the indus
componenttext: I mean, what you're seeing is competitive behavior in a slightly, just slightly unbalanced supply demand situation. And it's very typical. We saw -- we have never before seen in the industry four sequential quarters where the demand presented to the industry outstrip the industry's demand ability to supply. And it's pretty natural coming out of that pendulum is going to swing back a little the other way. It's very difficult to land without a little overshoot. And so I think what you've seen in the last six months has been the wealth created in the four-quarter runoff allowed people to encourage everybody to get more invested in the industry. And initially, as the demand softens, people have tried to maintain their momentum. And it takes a little while for folks to realize that if everybody overbuilds, then there's going to be pressure and then there's going to be -- our customers are smart people, they're going to take advantage of that. And we need to get things back in balance and move on with life. And that's the cycle that's been played through. I think if you analyze the numbers, however, you'll see that things are not a disaster right now. We finished last quarter above the bottom of our model. You can go back many years into the last 10 years and find periods where we dropped out of the model for periods of time, and I would remind you that the model was a significantly lower bottom to it than it has today. So the industry and WD have expanded the gross margin model consistently over the last 10 years, and we're still -- yes, we don't like being under the bottom of the model, and we're going to work to move ourselves back into it as soon as we can, but we're also willing to work to ensure that we have the right products set and the right availability and the right approach with our customers that has them prefer WD products over others and continue to grow our business profitably.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess as a follow-up then, should the message be then to investors that we could see bell curve where we had four kind of media order quarters and now you're going to have four quarters of some pretty challenging times. And I say that because if I think
componenttext: I guess as a follow-up then, should the message be then to investors that we could see bell curve where we had four kind of media order quarters and now you're going to have four quarters of some pretty challenging times. And I say that because if I think about industry to the industry's credit, you have a lot more efficient and effective participants than we did say, five or six years ago and as Rich alluded to earlier, it's going to be difficult to kind of reset the price curve, I think, for the time being.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The one I would say to investors is to look at the long-term demand for storage, the fact that the most appropriate solutions for mass volume storage is hard drives and to look at the long-term progress the industry has made in the last 10 years, and I be
componenttext: The one I would say to investors is to look at the long-term demand for storage, the fact that the most appropriate solutions for mass volume storage is hard drives and to look at the long-term progress the industry has made in the last 10 years, and I believe we will continue on that fundamental trend line over the next 10 years. In closing, I'd like to thank all of you for joining us today. We appreciate your questions and your interest in the company and in the industry. We look forward to seeing you again in another quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's First Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2011. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's First Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2011. [Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I want to mention, as we begin, that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and our response to your questions concerning the role and growth of digital content; growth opportunities for storage companies and our responses
componenttext:
Thank you. I want to mention, as we begin, that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and our response to your questions concerning the role and growth of digital content; growth opportunities for storage companies and our responses thereto; industry inventory; pricing and demand; our business model; our position in the industry; total available market for hard drives in the December quarter; our expected capital expenditures, depreciation and amortization and tax rate for fiscal 2011; our share repurchase plans; and our financial results, expectations for the December quarter, including revenue, expenses, tax rates, share count and earnings per share. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our 10-K filed with the SEC on August 13, 2010. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events, and you should not assume later in the quarter that the comments we make today are still valid.
I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investor section of Western Digital's website immediately following the conclusion of this call. I would now like turn to the call over to President and Chief Executive Officer of Western Digital, John Coyne.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. With me are Tim Leyden, recently named Chief Operating Officer; and Wolfgang Nickl, our newly appointed Chief Financial Officer. Although my titles of President and CEO are unchanged, m
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. With me are Tim Leyden, recently named Chief Operating Officer; and Wolfgang Nickl, our newly appointed Chief Financial Officer. 
Although my titles of President and CEO are unchanged, my emphasis has shifted to how we can best leverage our resources to accelerate our growth in the years ahead. As the new leader of all WD operations and keeper of our low cost model, Tim will discuss current industry dynamics and the company's performance in the September quarter while Wolfgang will report on our financial results and provide our outlook for the December quarter. With the advantage of a deeply experienced, dedicated and passionate team, we're excited as we lead WD into its fifth decade. 
As we look out over the next 10 years, the role of digital content in our daily lives at home and in the workplace will become increasingly ubiquitous, with the explosion of data and video rich applications creating huge amounts of digital content that need to be stored and managed. This will be driven by both the traditional computing markets and by new or evolutionary platforms such as handheld devices, televisions and other home entertainment devices where the analog to digital conversion is in its infancy. 
In addition to the continuing growth of traditional PC platforms, the growth of cloud computing, tablet computing and the proliferation of smartphones creates myriad opportunities for storage companies in traditional hard drive and emerging solid state drive markets. We will shape the future of WD by sorting through all these opportunities and acting decisively in our core business and in our business development efforts to continue delivering value to customers and shareholders. 
You have seen some early indications of one new strategic direction for WD into the movement of data and content around the home with our WD TV Live Media Players, our WD My Book Live network storage solutions and most recently, our WD Livewire powerline network offering. Going forward, we are looking for ways in which to pursue strategic growth initiatives such as this, both organically and through acquisition.
Turning to the current hard drive industry environment. We are again reminded that this is a competitive industry of seasons and cycles. The management of supply and demand remains an imperfect science. The moderation in industry demand growth in the last two quarters came on the heels of an unprecedented four quarters of strong sequential growth coming out of the great recession. As an industry, we clearly overshot the recent market demand, and we have spent the last six months correcting for that. We believe this will prove to be an interlude to the resumption of the industry's traditional cadence of growth over the last 10 years. 
Having said this, it's important to note that growth has not disappeared in the hard drive industry post recession. Expected year-on-year volume growth in calendar year 2010 of 15% brings the five-year industry compound growth rate, which includes the recession of late 2008 to about 11%, while the average growth rate over the last 10 years has been 12.5%. 
In the last two quarters, some competitors have made aggressive bids to recover market share. This is a scenario we have seen play out from time to time over the years in the drive industry. Our observation is that these are temporary skirmishes, which do not derail our fundamental long-term profitable growth story as we address these challenges with the tested business model we have developed and honed over time.
For the last 10 years, WD has been navigating these industry swings and consistently winning share with our focus on customer value by having the lowest cost model in the industry. We have grown revenues by 18% annually over the last 10 years and by 22% annually for the last five years by providing exceptional value to our customers through the high quality, reliability and desirability of our products along with predictable availability and competitive prices. At the same time, we have expanded our full year gross margins from 11% in 2001 to 24% in 2010. This was accomplished primarily through successful vertical integration, expanding our product breadth, delighting our customers and execution of our low-cost model. We will continue with this approach as we go forward. Tim Leyden, will now comment on how the September quarter played out for WD and the industry.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As John indicated, we have navigated through multiple market-driven supply/demand imbalances in the hard drive industry. And WD remains prepared to address them with what we believe is the industry's lowest cost model. Continuing our unwavering
componenttext:
Thank you. As John indicated, we have navigated through multiple market-driven supply/demand imbalances in the hard drive industry. And WD remains prepared to address them with what we believe is the industry's lowest cost model. Continuing our unwavering focus on low-cost leadership is my top priority in my new position. This couples with the focus on staying on the industry area density curve, a continued appreciation of customer needs and a broad and diverse set of competitive product offerings in all segments will keep us in an advantage position. This proven approach to the hard drive business has served us, our customers and our shareholders well for the last 10 years. 
As John mentioned earlier, we saw an unprecedented four consecutive quarters of increasing hard drive shipments from April 2009 to March 2010. And it is now apparent that we have been experiencing a correction of PC makers inventories beginning in the June quarter of this year. 
Despite weak demand for the first two months of the September quarter and the quieter-than-normal back-to-school season, industry shipments nevertheless climbed towards the high end of our 165 million unit forecast for the September quarter. But to accomplish this, shipment volumes in week 13 were over twice the average of the previous 12 weeks. 
In light of the sluggish demand in July and August, we reduced our build plans for September, delayed our capital spending and selectively stepped back from participating in some very aggressive pricing at the end of the quarter. The lower-than-expected demand earlier in the quarter led to a build-up of manufacturers inventory during the first eight weeks of the quarter. And contrary to prior fiscal first quarter historical trend, this contributed to aggressive pricing during the reminder of the quarter. 
We maintained share in the 3.5-inch market and yielded 1.5 points of share in 2.5-inch as a result of our temporary process. We exited the quarter with well-controlled inventories in each of our segments. 
We expect that the incremental part of the week 13 shipments will be consumed during the current quarter because customers will not wish to carry this inventory into a seasonally weaker March quarter. And we believe this sets the stage for a TAM in the December quarter that will be essentially flat with the September quarter.
We believe that HDD hardware and software are pivotal to the data and content management infrastructure ecosystem. The value delivers is not proportionately rewarded in the broader market space, particularly even the level of unique skills and investments in technology and capital are taken into consideration. 
Consequently, we under the midst of reviewing the comparative returns on investments that we are currently achieving across our customer and product ranges, with the view to reaching the levels of ROI we need in order to continue investing and to provide a product availability that the market demands. As the industry's lowest cost provider, we believe that it is in the best interest of our customers and shareholders that we offer products at a price that covers the cost of doing business and provides the margin and the funding required to continue investing in order to remain a valued HDD supplier on a long-term sustainable basis.
Looking at our served markets in the September quarter. In the compute space, we saw a continuation of softness in consumer demand in all channels, with somewhat of an offset coming from healthier desktop and commercial notebook demand. We expect desktop demand to be marginally down and notebook demand to be marginally up in the December quarter. 
In the Enterprise segment, we saw a continued demand strength particularly in Enterprise SATA with the traditional Enterprise segment being essentially flat sequentially. We expect overall Enterprise demand to show us some modest growth in the December quarter. 
In the non-compute space, we saw the CE market volumes decline marginally quarter-on-quarter as the market tracked historical seasonal demand patterns. At the same time, the branded products market showed seasonal demand strength to both 3.5-inch and 2.5-inch categories showing growth. We expect the non-compute space to be essentially flat in the December quarter, and healthy volume increases in branded and CE are offset by the seasonal declines in gaming volume. 
Geographically, Asia has showed continued strength. Europe showed the best comparative improvements from the previous quarter helped by the currency appreciation, while the U.S. market was up modestly from the prior quarter. 
We shipped 50.7 million units in the September quarter, up 15% from the year-ago period while the overall market grew by 8%. Revenues totaled $2.4 billion, gross margin was 18.2%, and we remain solidly profitable with net income of $197 million.  Importantly, we continue to generate strong cash flow from operations of $390 million.
We continue to invest in the business and are doing so by improving and expanding our operations and by enhancing our product lineup, both in our industry-leading hard drive offerings and in the recent but promising market for management of content in the home. 
In our traditional businesses, we delivered new models of our popular My Book and My Passport external hard drives with USB 3.0 connectivity and up to three terabytes of storage. Significantly improving content transfer speed and providing our customers with future proofing as newer PCs and other devices began shipping in volume with USB 3.0. And in the component space, we began shipping the highest area of infancy, 3.5-inch hard drive in the industry, the WD Caviar bringing three terabytes, which fits 750 gigabytes on each of its four platters. 
Reflecting our increasing focus on enabling our comprehensive and easy-to-use experience for management of content in the home, we've added several new products and features including the WD Livewire powerline AV network kit, a home plugged AV compatible solution that enables consumers to use their existing electrical wiring to extend secure high-speed Internet connection throughout the home. 
The My Book Live home network drive, which gives consumers the fastest storage of and access to their content and provides the same set up centralizing digital media in the home. The one terabyte WD Elements play multimedia drive, with high-definition capability onboard, and we also recently introduced the newest version of WD Photos, our photo viewer application now optimize for the iPad, the iPhone 4 and iPod Touch. WD Photos enable users to view photos stored on their WD home network drive from any location. I will now turn the call over to Wolfgang Nickl for a review of our Q1 financial performance and our outlook for the second quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tim. I would like to refer you to a new and expanded summary of financial information that has been posted to the Investor Relations section of our website. Much of the data that we have recited during past conference calls is included in that
componenttext:
Thank you, Tim. I would like to refer you to a new and expanded summary of financial information that has been posted to the Investor Relations section of our website. Much of the data that we have recited during past conference calls is included in that fact sheet. During my prepared remarks, I will focus on highlights and significant changes in some of our key metrics. At the end of this call, the summary of financial information will be updated to include our Q2 guidance, which I will discuss in a few moments.
The September quarter was characterized by unusually aggressive pricing that lasted throughout the quarter with like-for-like prices decline in excess of 8%. Pricing pressure was most prevalent in the 2.5-inch segment. We made a conscious decision to limit our participation in the segment in an effort to optimize profitability. Our flexible operating model allowed us to adjust our operating expenses to offset the impact of pricing on operating margin and closed the quarter near the midpoint of our EPS guidance range. 
We actively managed capital receipts and working capital and generated significant free cash flow. Revenue for the first fiscal quarter was $2.4 billion, up 9% from the prior year and 1% sequentially. This include its $51 million of sales of media from our newly acquired Singapore media facility to fulfill contractual obligation carrying over from Hoya's existing sales commitment. We do not expect any external media sales in Q2. 
Authorized shipments totaled 50.7 million units, up 15% from the prior year period and 2% sequentially. Revenue from sales of WD TV Media Player, WD Livewire network kit and stock solid state drive totals approximately $33 million, roughly flat with the prior year and up 22% from the June quarter. 
Average hard drive selling price was approximately $46 per unit, down $3 from the year-ago quarter and down $1 from the June quarter. Revenue from sales of our branded products including WD TV and WD Livewire product was $425 million, up 11% from $382 million in the year-ago quarter and 6% sequentially from $400 million in the June quarter. 
There was no customer that comprised 10% or more of our total revenue. Our first margin for the quarter was 18.2%, down from 23.3% in the year-ago quarter and down from 22.5% in the June quarter. The lower-than-expected gross margin percentage was primarily due to the price declines I referred to earlier. Products and segment mix, as well as product cost declines, were largely in line with our expectations.
Total R&D and SG&A spending was $226 million or 9.4% of revenue. This compares with $195 million or 8.8% of revenue in the year-ago quarter and $242 million or 10.2% of revenue in the June quarter. As a reminder, total operating expenses for the June quarter include a $27 million of litigation settlement. 
Operating income was $211 million or 8.8% of revenue. This compares with $319 million or 14.4% of revenue in the year-ago quarter and $293 million or 12.3% of revenue in the June quarter. Net interest and other non-operating expenses were less than $1 million. 
Tax expense for the September quarter was $14 million or 6.6% of pretax income. Our net income totaled $197 million or $0.84 per share. This compares with $288 million or $1.25 per share and $265 million or $1.13 per share in the year-ago and June quarters, respectively.
Turning to the balance sheet. We generated $390 million in cash flow from operations during the September quarter. Our cash conversion cycle for the first quarter was a negative three days. This consisted of 50 days of receivables outstanding, 26 days of inventory or 14 turns and 79 days of payables. 
Capital addition for the September quarter totaled $200 million, lower than our July projections of $275 million as we scaled back in line with lower shipments. Depreciation and amortization expense for the first quarter totaled $115 million. We continue to expect our capital expenditure for fiscal 2011 to be between 7% and 8% of revenue with an additional $200 million related to our 6-inch to 8-inch wafer conversion and some expenditures to optimize the output from our recently acquired media facility in Singapore. Depreciation and amortization is expected to be at about $630 million for the fiscal year. 
We made $25 million of debt repayment installments during the first quarter, and thereby reduced our debt balance to $375 million. We exited fiscal Q1 with cash and cash equivalent of $2.9 billion, an increase of $124 million from the June quarter. Here in the quarter, we repurchased 1.8 million shares at a total cost of $50 million. The balance remaining on our stock repurchase authorization is $416 million. From a balance sheet strategy perspective, our first priority is to create shareholder value through strategic investments both in markets currently served and adjacent markets. Any larger scale share buybacks would be considered only after we have exhausted our strategic options. 
Now turning to our expectations for fiscal Q2. Historically, industry shipment increased by 5% to 7% from the September to the December quarter. As Tim mentioned, we have seen approximately twice the shipment volume in the last week of last quarter than an average of the preceding 12 weeks of the quarter. We believe that customers will not want to carry extra inventory into the March quarter and therefore, expect some inventory correction. We consequently assume that the December quarter industry TAM will be roughly flat with the September quarter at around 165 million units. 
Some of the aggressive pricing we have seen last quarter is carried over into this quarter, and our guidance includes like-for-like pricing line of approximately 5%. We are actively reviewing our planned shipment portfolio to identify business that is not meeting our business model requirements. Where contractual obligations do not exist, we may refuse our shipments of low contribution products and seek to shift sales to more profitable segments. 
As previously indicated, we are currently calibrating our new Singapore media facility through our own recipes, and as a result, we are experiencing a dilution of first margin of 50 basis points during this quarter. Accordingly, our guidance for fiscal Q2 is as follows. We expect revenue to be in the range from $2.3 billion to $2.4 billion. R&D and SG&A spending is expected to total approximately $230 million. Our net interest expense is projected to be about $1 million. Expect our tax rate to be within our business model of 6% to 9%. We anticipate our share count to be approximately $235 million. We estimate earnings per share of between $0.50 and $0.60 for the December quarter. Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.
