componenttext: We don't really have a much insight into that at this particular point, Richard. But we are looking at how it might impact us. We've got pretty good relationships with our vendor, and we're looking to leverage those in order to make sure that we are minimally impacted.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just lastly, traditionally, the industry has been able to offset price declines by moving to new product lines. There has been largely an absence of new products here in the second half of calendar '10. They're supposed to be some new products coming out
componenttext: Just lastly, traditionally, the industry has been able to offset price declines by moving to new product lines. There has been largely an absence of new products here in the second half of calendar '10. They're supposed to be some new products coming out in the first half of '11. Do you think that that's the opportunity to go and maybe reset this cost price situation? Any thoughts so what we might be able to see a stabilization of the pricing environment?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we've seen previously from history is that the stabilization of the pricing environment comes when demand exceeds supply, and that has generally been going to the seasonal cadence. It's generally beyond the September and December quarters. So with th
componenttext: What we've seen previously from history is that the stabilization of the pricing environment comes when demand exceeds supply, and that has generally been going to the seasonal cadence. It's generally beyond the September and December quarters. So with the working off of the inventory that has occurred during the course of the September quarter and with the HDD market being up about by 5% versus what would normally be a much stronger position somewhere in the 10% to 12%, I would imagine. And going into a December quarter that's essentially flat, we think that the opportunity will come more from supply chain demand again. So we think that the industry will have to manage the inventory supply/demand equilibrium and stabilize that situation, and that will have more of an impact on us than any of the new products as such.

And I would say this is the main contributor to the decline quarter-over-quarter.

componenttext: The expense going up, if you take the $242 million from the June quarter and normalize for the $27 million and then the increase in expense comes mainly from an adjusted in our incentive accruals and then from investments in our Research and Development teams and in our sales teams to increase our market reach.

And so we have no reason to believe that, that will change whether they're public or private. They will remain a respected and formidable competitor in the space.

componenttext: And then in terms of the gross margin now being down below your targeted range, we're heading into after December were into the March and the June quarters when industry demand is typically down. It seems like that won't happen until the second half of 2011 at the earliest.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wolfgang again. As I mentioned, price decline is a very important contributor to this equation. We're in control of our cost declines, and we're working on our channel mix. So it will come down to when the supply/demand situation will allow pricing to sta
componenttext: Wolfgang again. As I mentioned, price decline is a very important contributor to this equation. We're in control of our cost declines, and we're working on our channel mix. So it will come down to when the supply/demand situation will allow pricing to stabilize. And we're not making any predictions when that would happen, but we'll know that the margin for June quarter usually is seasonally soft.

componenttext: We're just going on what expectations were like and things coming into the year. There was expectations that the industry demand would be somewhere in the 170 million units to 180 million units type of number. So consequently, we're running at about 165 and if you take the midpoint of the 170 to 180 million units, you're probably looking at being somewhere between 90% and 95%. You just take the straight math, 165 to 175 is about 94%, so it's probably somewhere in the 90% to 95% range.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: And is it -- I think, you said it was more notebooks but was it collective, so to speak? I know you guys said you elected not to participate but were there many fingerprints on the drives?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't actually mention that we elected not to participate. We mentioned that we selectively stepped back. In addition to that, even though it's a higher number than we what we would normally see, there's always some extra amount that gets shipped in a
componenttext: We didn't actually mention that we elected not to participate. We mentioned that we selectively stepped back. In addition to that, even though it's a higher number than we what we would normally see, there's always some extra amount that gets shipped in at the end of each quarter. So the excess over and above what would normally happen is probably somewhere in the region of about 5 million units or so. And so that has to get worked up, obviously, going into a quarter, which is front-end loaded as opposed to the previous two quarters, which have been heavily back-end loaded. So there's an opportunity for that inventory to get burned off early. We'll just have to wait and see what happens.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: My follow-up then, Tim, is just curious to your discussions with the OEMs as it relates to the demand on the notebook side versus the potential conflict or demand conflict with tablets. How are the OEMs characterizing? And how does that make you think abo
componenttext: My follow-up then, Tim, is just curious to your discussions with the OEMs as it relates to the demand on the notebook side versus the potential conflict or demand conflict with tablets. How are the OEMs characterizing? And how does that make you think about the seasonality in notebook drives in the March quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is John. I'll take this tablet question. From everything we can gather with multiple different source reporting on tablets, I mean we see the first two quarters of the iPad is about 8 million units, to put it in context, that compares with the first
componenttext: This is John. I'll take this tablet question. From everything we can gather with multiple different source reporting on tablets, I mean we see the first two quarters of the iPad is about 8 million units, to put it in context, that compares with the first two quarters of the EPC netbook emergence, which was 5 million units first two quarters. So everything we hear indicates that roughly half of the iPad sales are to existing Apple households, and that somewhere in the region of 13% to 15% of the folks buying iPads admit to substituting the iPad for a previously planned PC purchase. And some 23% of purchasers indicate they're buying an iPad as an alternative to a Kindle or other eReader. So what we see, I think, is a complementary additional device sale to the overall ecosystem of content consumption. We think that when you look at the numbers, certainly, there has been some falloff in netbook over the last couple of quarters. They're also -- you have to take the price point of the iPad into account, so likely that over the next several quarters as other tablets emerge, they will address lower price points than the iPad currently occupies. But on overall assessment, we're seeing maybe somewhere in the 10% to 20% impact range on the growth of low-end notebooks, netbook products.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ben Reitzes with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Ben Reitzes with Barclays Capital.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about going beyond the December quarter, if you could, just about some dynamics that are setting up. There's Intel Sandy Bridge which may affect some of the builds from the OEM customers and then there's the emergence of China, which is ki
componenttext: I wanted to ask about going beyond the December quarter, if you could, just about some dynamics that are setting up. There's Intel Sandy Bridge which may affect some of the builds from the OEM customers and then there's the emergence of China, which is kind of changing the seasonality of the whole world. So is there a chance that TAM is flattish like it was again like what it was last year in the March quarter? And does the March quarter potentially represents some light at the end of the tunnel here after this big quarter of adjustment in December?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there is a chance. I mean, March quarter traditionally, if we go back to the pre-recession cadence, was just slightly down and somewhere in the maybe 3% region. And from a going-forward seasonal viewpoint, it does look as if the strength of C
componenttext: Yes, I think there is a chance. I mean, March quarter traditionally, if we go back to the pre-recession cadence, was just slightly down and somewhere in the maybe 3% region. And from a going-forward seasonal viewpoint, it does look as if the strength of China is changing that dynamic. So there is opportunity there for the situation to improve. So we'll wait and see. But I mean, it's all dependent on the working through the inventory that the PC OEMs have built up and how they manage that than how the difference there has been the disk drive industry and managed the shipment going into the market. So there's a lot of dynamics on it, but there is an opportunity considering the changing variables that are going such as the Intel Sandy Bridge, the Chinese New Year and the strength of fourth Christmas sales as well. So there's opportunity, and we'll have to wait for it.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I wanted to just address the NAND issue again perhaps with Apple having an event tomorrow where they might introduce more NAND into the MacBook Air and whatnot. Is there anything changed more in the mainstream PC market? Or is there any worries a
componenttext: And then I wanted to just address the NAND issue again perhaps with Apple having an event tomorrow where they might introduce more NAND into the MacBook Air and whatnot. Is there anything changed more in the mainstream PC market? Or is there any worries about what Apple may do actually more of the mainstream PC market with NAND? Or is that a status quo still right now where it's too expensive and it's not going to happen and it's just going to be in the iPad market or at the tablet market?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we believe that the solid state solutions are not competitive in the mainstream PC market whether laptop or desktop. The economics just don't work out. Where the storage element is constrained by form factor, then on a high price point devices, solid
componenttext: Yes, we believe that the solid state solutions are not competitive in the mainstream PC market whether laptop or desktop. The economics just don't work out. Where the storage element is constrained by form factor, then on a high price point devices, solid state is an appropriate solution and where in the very small form factor devices like PDAs, MP3 players and so on. It's clear that small amounts of solid state memory are the solution to fit in the form factor and fit in the budget.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Nashal Toski with Technology Insights Research.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010

componenttext: Your enterprise industry was down Q2 compared to what it's typically in up Q. Can you talk about what drove that?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're going through some product transitions in there. We had a very strong product line up, and we're now moving into a period in which we will have some product transitions. We expect to work through those in two or three quarters.
componenttext: We're going through some product transitions in there. We had a very strong product line up, and we're now moving into a period in which we will have some product transitions. We expect to work through those in two or three quarters.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is that a SAS based transition? Or SATA based transition?
componenttext: Is that a SAS based transition? Or SATA based transition?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a SATA based transition.
componenttext: It's a SATA based transition.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then at the beginning of the call, John, you talked about how you're putting a little bit larger focus on some specific directions. It seems like you're trying to talk about more focus on the user that implies putting greater focus on software. Can yo
componenttext: And then at the beginning of the call, John, you talked about how you're putting a little bit larger focus on some specific directions. It seems like you're trying to talk about more focus on the user that implies putting greater focus on software. Can you just give us some metrics that verifies that this is being the case possibly maybe a number of software engineers at WD, how that's growing or maybe R&D spend dedicated software? Can you talk a little bit to that?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I will not give you specifics on that for competitive reasons, but if you look at the trust of our product offerings in our branded business, you'll note that we've migrated the backup software, on all of our drive products, the My Book and the My Passpor
componenttext: I will not give you specifics on that for competitive reasons, but if you look at the trust of our product offerings in our branded business, you'll note that we've migrated the backup software, on all of our drive products, the My Book and the My Passport line, which used to be a purchased software solution we have migrated to an internally developed solutions so that we can better own the total customer experience there and the interaction of the customer with the device. If you look at our complete range of WD media players, the TV Live line and the Elements play line, there, again, you'll see significant software content in those products. And then you look at the our recent launch of the WD Photo app for the iPad, iPhone 4, and iPod Touch, again an in-house developed software product. So also, some years ago, you will recall we bought a company called [indiscernible] which was a software play that we have developed into the major engine that creates the connectivity and accessibility for all of our products as they interplay for remote access. So yes, we're putting significant emphasis on software these days.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rob Cihra with Caris & Company.
componenttext: Rob Cihra with Caris & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: One just on CapEx. It did come in a little lower in dollar terms and you mentioned you're still looking at the same target as a percentage of revenue and including the 8-inch wafer conversion. But can you tell us what you've seen maybe from sort of across
componenttext: One just on CapEx. It did come in a little lower in dollar terms and you mentioned you're still looking at the same target as a percentage of revenue and including the 8-inch wafer conversion. But can you tell us what you've seen maybe from sort of across the industry in terms of other players, if you've seen people already cutting CapEx measurably or just starting to a little bit including, for example, Asian media suppliers. Do you think that's going to help anytime soon or are we too early for CapEx cuts to the help? And then separate from that, if I could just push maybe a little more, you did touch on almost the $11 in cash per share that you have. I'm just wondering if you push a little more in terms of what your priorities are in terms of buybacks versus potential dividend and versus acquisitions.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, from a CapEx viewpoint, we don't really have much than our competitors. We would imagine that by past history that people are -- since the volumes are coming in lower than what pipeline have anticipated in September and December quarters of our sect
componenttext: Okay, from a CapEx viewpoint, we don't really have much than our competitors. We would imagine that by past history that people are -- since the volumes are coming in lower than what pipeline have anticipated in September and December quarters of our section for TAM being flattish from September is correct. We would imagine that everybody is moving to postpone and cancel their profitable capital additions and managing it as prudently as they possibly can. In our case, we have demonstrated that capability over a long period of time. We add capacity just in time, and we managed capacity on an ongoing basis in order to cover the demand at that point in time.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of balance sheet and stock rebooked as a strategy, as John mentioned in his remarks, our prime focus right now is to evaluate strategic opportunities, what was in 8 gbs as well as in the adjacent markets, and we'll use our cash and our borrowing
componenttext: In terms of balance sheet and stock rebooked as a strategy, as John mentioned in his remarks, our prime focus right now is to evaluate strategic opportunities, what was in 8 gbs as well as in the adjacent markets, and we'll use our cash and our borrowing capacity to accomplish that. And once we have reviewed all these opportunities and will show that we can't find anything appropriate, we will evaluate the best way of returning money to the shareholder, and that could be in the form of share buybacks, and we'll decide whether we do that in a unleveled or leveled fashion at the appropriate point in time.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark Miller with Noble Financial.
componenttext: Mark Miller with Noble Financial.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back and talk about pricing again, because these margins were I think below most of what people thought, you indicated inventory. How much -- you're roughly split 50/50 between the OEM and the channel and retail. How much of the pricing pre
componenttext: I wanted to go back and talk about pricing again, because these margins were I think below most of what people thought, you indicated inventory. How much -- you're roughly split 50/50 between the OEM and the channel and retail. How much of the pricing pressure or the decrease in margins is due to pricing from the OEM options? And how much of it is in your anticipated pricing pressures in the channel?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there has been more pricing pressure coming from OEM. And because during the four quarters of unprecedented demand outstripping supply, the OEMs got nervous about supply, it's up from inventory positions within their own internal inventory. And th
componenttext: I think there has been more pricing pressure coming from OEM. And because during the four quarters of unprecedented demand outstripping supply, the OEMs got nervous about supply, it's up from inventory positions within their own internal inventory. And then we came on a little consumer softness, as they let the inventory correct and then sat back and got some improved pricing conditions as a result of that. And so that dynamic is the more important one in the overall pricing movement. There has been some pressure in the channel as well as in the last couple of quarters you've had given competitors trying to gain back market share that they had lost in earlier quarters and has put some pressure on the channels. But I think the OEM pricing pressure has been more significant.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one final question. You are going through a major ramp in your head fabs and also, I think expanding into a new fab in the old thermal way facility. Have you had to buy more components externally than you have in previous quarters? Or are you still s
componenttext: Just one final question. You are going through a major ramp in your head fabs and also, I think expanding into a new fab in the old thermal way facility. Have you had to buy more components externally than you have in previous quarters? Or are you still supplying at roughly the same mix internally and externally especially for heads and as well as media by the way?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have very good relationships with the external merchant vendors, and we've got our own internal component operating rather well. So we operate in order to -- we mix both in order to optimize our profit objectives. And that fluctuates around from somewh
componenttext: We have very good relationships with the external merchant vendors, and we've got our own internal component operating rather well. So we operate in order to -- we mix both in order to optimize our profit objectives. And that fluctuates around from somewhere around 75% to 85% internally. And so we continue to work that. That's not a perfect science as you can imagine so it's -- we're continuing to work with them as we always do.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So there's no major change in your mix so just roughly small change in your mix between internal and external components supply expected for the December quarter as what you've seen in the recent quarters?
componenttext: So there's no major change in your mix so just roughly small change in your mix between internal and external components supply expected for the December quarter as what you've seen in the recent quarters?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, other than, of course, the impact of the Singapore and client facility that will change the dynamics and increase the internal for media.
componenttext: No, other than, of course, the impact of the Singapore and client facility that will change the dynamics and increase the internal for media.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kaushik Roy with Wedbush.
componenttext: Kaushik Roy with Wedbush.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: So going back to the question of Seagate, how do you see the markets evolving if Seagate goes private? I mean, do you expect less pricing pressure or not really?
componenttext: So going back to the question of Seagate, how do you see the markets evolving if Seagate goes private? I mean, do you expect less pricing pressure or not really?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Based on history, we don't perceive that private or public ownership had any significant impact on how Seagate address the market and how we address the market. So I mean, we're focus on how we continue to find the recipe that the lights customers and doe
componenttext: Based on history, we don't perceive that private or public ownership had any significant impact on how Seagate address the market and how we address the market. So I mean, we're focus on how we continue to find the recipe that the lights customers and does so based off having the lowest cost in the industry so that we can convert that customer delight despite competitive environment into significant profitability and growth. And so we don't see the company ownership fees as a very significant element in all of that.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then you said that SSDs are not competitive on desktop, and notebook, but can you comment on your progress on SSDs? Are you willing to participate in the Enterprise segment or the small Form Factor segment?
componenttext: And then you said that SSDs are not competitive on desktop, and notebook, but can you comment on your progress on SSDs? Are you willing to participate in the Enterprise segment or the small Form Factor segment?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the company we acquired a couple of years ago, we have worked on that embedded market for netcom and industrial controls and so on. And we have grown that business since acquisition, we're committed to that space. We have produced products for the cl
componenttext: Yes, the company we acquired a couple of years ago, we have worked on that embedded market for netcom and industrial controls and so on. And we have grown that business since acquisition, we're committed to that space. We have produced products for the client space. That's very low volume. And we are working diligently on product for the enterprise space, which we believe is the most attractive application for solid state drives, attractive to the customer because of the value it brings, attractive to us because of the value that we bring to the knowledge in the area of applications and management of media. And so that's our primary focus for now is on the development trail to broaden our enterprise portfolio offering.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you quantify the units or revenues in any way?
componenttext: Can you quantify the units or revenues in any way?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think that the enterprise, solid state enterprise market today is somewhere in the $800 million to $1 billion range. And as we assess the various forecast that are out there from multiple sources and our own take on that, we're looking at that market a
componenttext: We think that the enterprise, solid state enterprise market today is somewhere in the $800 million to $1 billion range. And as we assess the various forecast that are out there from multiple sources and our own take on that, we're looking at that market as being a $3 billion to $5 billion market in three to five years.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next comes from Ananda Baruah with Brean Murray.
componenttext: The next comes from Ananda Baruah with Brean Murray.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, just wanted to ask your take on given that after this quarter, it sounds like, there's still going to be, I don't know, you say, 7 million to 10 million drives of excess inventory out there for the industry. Might it be, I guess, more prudent ship,
componenttext: John, just wanted to ask your take on given that after this quarter, it sounds like, there's still going to be, I don't know, you say, 7 million to 10 million drives of excess inventory out there for the industry. Might it be, I guess, more prudent ship, I guess, sort of TAM down in the December quarter versus September just to get that out of the way more quickly? Or is there something structural just about the way that you take down the industry if we take down built into the quarter that precluded that from being done?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our take on the time and calling the time flat quarter-to-quarter is we believe the underlying demand is off quarter-to-quarter. We think it's seasonal and will likely be up in the 5% range on a quarter-over-quarter basis, and we're calling the drive indu
componenttext: Our take on the time and calling the time flat quarter-to-quarter is we believe the underlying demand is off quarter-to-quarter. We think it's seasonal and will likely be up in the 5% range on a quarter-over-quarter basis, and we're calling the drive industry TAM flat so that the inventory that has been built up can be absorbed into the market demand.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any sense, or is it too early to get a sense, if taking out through the inventory that will be taken out during the December quarter by shipping the flat TAM? Will that make a meaningful difference in the promotion of more normal seasonal pricing in the M
componenttext: Any sense, or is it too early to get a sense, if taking out through the inventory that will be taken out during the December quarter by shipping the flat TAM? Will that make a meaningful difference in the promotion of more normal seasonal pricing in the March quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think March quarter and the thesis has yet to be proven. But we do believe that there is some shift to the overall traditional seasonality of the industry and unfortunately, the timing of the big recession and the recovery out of that makes it a very di
componenttext: I think March quarter and the thesis has yet to be proven. But we do believe that there is some shift to the overall traditional seasonality of the industry and unfortunately, the timing of the big recession and the recovery out of that makes it a very difficult to clearly discern shifts in the multiyear seasonal patterns, but we do believe that there's a specialty of the rise of China as an important market, creating demand in the first calendar quarter of the year. We believe there's a shift from air freight to sea freight from Asia to the U.S. and Europe causing a shift, a pull forward of back-to-school bills into the second calendar quarter of the year and that over time, the seasonality of the business will flatten out. It's difficult to get a precise handle on that because of the massive disruption that the recession put on top of those patterns.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to come back to what is going on here over the past six months or so, John and Tim, if you could kind of weigh in here, is there something structurally wrong right now with the overall disk drive industry in terms of how industry interfaces with
componenttext: I wanted to come back to what is going on here over the past six months or so, John and Tim, if you could kind of weigh in here, is there something structurally wrong right now with the overall disk drive industry in terms of how industry interfaces with both the OEMs and distributors? And I think back to 2004, how the results and what are the challenges in any industry participants worth to have greater transparency and greater dialogue to manage the inventories in the supply/demand and balances, because I just got confused when you can have the huge 13th week and then certainly, the spigot gets turned off again by the OEMs. I mean, do they have these quick static demand cycles? Who's kind of at fault here in terms of what's going on?

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, what you're seeing is competitive behavior in a slightly, just slightly unbalanced supply demand situation. And it's very typical. We saw -- we have never before seen in the industry four sequential quarters where the demand presented to the indus
componenttext: I mean, what you're seeing is competitive behavior in a slightly, just slightly unbalanced supply demand situation. And it's very typical. We saw -- we have never before seen in the industry four sequential quarters where the demand presented to the industry outstrip the industry's demand ability to supply. And it's pretty natural coming out of that pendulum is going to swing back a little the other way. It's very difficult to land without a little overshoot. And so I think what you've seen in the last six months has been the wealth created in the four-quarter runoff allowed people to encourage everybody to get more invested in the industry. And initially, as the demand softens, people have tried to maintain their momentum. And it takes a little while for folks to realize that if everybody overbuilds, then there's going to be pressure and then there's going to be -- our customers are smart people, they're going to take advantage of that. And we need to get things back in balance and move on with life. And that's the cycle that's been played through. I think if you analyze the numbers, however, you'll see that things are not a disaster right now. We finished last quarter above the bottom of our model. You can go back many years into the last 10 years and find periods where we dropped out of the model for periods of time, and I would remind you that the model was a significantly lower bottom to it than it has today. So the industry and WD have expanded the gross margin model consistently over the last 10 years, and we're still -- yes, we don't like being under the bottom of the model, and we're going to work to move ourselves back into it as soon as we can, but we're also going to work to ensure that we have the right products set and the right availability and the right approach with our customers that has them prefer WD products over others and continue to grow our business profitably.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess as a follow-up then, should the message be then to investors that we could see bell curve where we had four kind of meteoric quarters and now you have four quarters of some pretty challenging times? And I say that because if I think about industry
componenttext: I guess as a follow-up then, should the message be then to investors that we could see bell curve where we had four kind of meteoric quarters and now you have four quarters of some pretty challenging times? And I say that because if I think about industry to the industry's credit, you have a lot more efficient and effective participants than we did say, five or six years ago and as Rich alluded to earlier, it's going to be difficult to kind of reset the price curve, I think, for the time being.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: The one I would say to investors is to look at the long-term demand for storage, the fact that the most appropriate solutions for mass volume storage is hard drives and to look at the long-term progress the industry has made in the last 10 years, and I be
componenttext: The one I would say to investors is to look at the long-term demand for storage, the fact that the most appropriate solutions for mass volume storage is hard drives and to look at the long-term progress the industry has made in the last 10 years, and I believe we will continue on that fundamental trend line over the next 10 years. In closing, I'd like to thank all of you for joining us today. We appreciate your questions and your interest in the company and in the industry. We look forward to seeing you again in another quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This does conclude today's conference. You may disconnect at this time.
componenttext: Thank you. This does conclude today's conference. You may disconnect at this time.
